metadata.sermon_start_end: The performance artist Laurie Anderson, whose new show is opening at the Brooklyn Academy of Music next week, is a reader of the Bible and the literary classics. [...] This very day he might be calling you to perform a miracle of love and humility that you never thought you were capable of. And you know what? It will make you laugh. It will be both fun and funny. 'Rejoice in the Lord always; again I will say, Rejoice' (Phil. 4:4). AMEN.
metadata.liturgical_context: October 3, 1999; Christ Church, Sheffield, MA. Includes children and youth.
metadata.historical_context: Late 20th-century America, shortly after the Columbine High School shooting (referenced in text). Context of 'New Homiletic' influence.
metadata.notes: The sermon bridges high Christology with contemporary performance art and pop culture.

criterion_a1_imagery.analysis: The sermon utilizes effective, concrete imagery to bridge the gap between ancient text and modern listeners. Rutledge avoids the trap of abstract dogmatics by grounding the 'kenosis' (emptying) of Christ in tangible comparisons. She contrasts the 'form of God' with the 'Bill Gates or Donald Trump' of the time, providing a sharp, socio-economic image of power that the congregation can immediately visualize. The description of the cross is particularly strong, moving beyond the 'jewelry' version of the crucifix to the 'side of the road' reality of Roman execution. By using the 'ugly people' metaphor from Laurie Anderson's song, she creates a recurring visual motif for human sinfulness and divine grace. However, some sections remain slightly more 'telling' than 'showing' when explaining the mechanics of the atonement, though the overall sensory engagement remains high for a mixed-age audience.
quotes: God became a human baby and was born in the same messy way that all human babies are born.
He had to walk everywhere because he had no money to pay for an animal to ride on.
People were put on crosses by the side of the road; you couldn’t miss them.
strengths: Effective use of contemporary icons (Gates/Trump) to illustrate power.
Visceral description of the 'messy' incarnation and the 'degrading' cross.
Creative appropriation of the 'ugly people' metaphor to describe the human condition.
improvement_points: Could further develop the sensory aspects of the 'church carpet' conflict to make the 'strife' more palpable.
The 'pure light/pure power' description of heaven is somewhat conventional; fresher metaphors for the divine realm could enhance the contrast.
More 'showing' of the 'miracle of love' in the conclusion would strengthen the final impact.
criterion_a1_imagery.show_vs_tell_balance: Strong balance; uses 'showing' through historical and contemporary parallels to explain 'telling' theological concepts.

criterion_a2_carefulness_and_precision.analysis: Rutledge demonstrates exceptional stewardship of language. She avoids 'Canaanite' jargon, even when dealing with complex concepts like the 'morphe' of God. Instead of hiding behind the term 'kenosis,' she explains it through the lens of 'reputation' and 'emptying.' Her word choice is precise and economical, particularly when addressing the children in the room without condescending to the adults. She nuances human motivation carefully, as seen in her analysis of the kidney donor story—distinguishing between 'noble' acts and 'heroic' needs. The language is loving yet firm, refusing to smooth over the 'godless death' of Jesus. Every sentence serves a purpose, and the transition from the 'Big Idea' to the 'ugly people' shows a high degree of rhetorical control and linguistic care.
quotes: The Son of God made himself of no reputation at all.
It was a method specifically designed to be as degrading and dehumanizing as possible.
Human love is not good enough. We have strayed too far from the center of God’s will.
strengths: Clear, jargon-free explanation of the Greek 'morphe' and 'doulos'.
Nuanced description of human selfishness that avoids simplistic moralism.
High level of clarity suitable for a multi-generational audience.
improvement_points: The transition between the kidney donor story and the Laurie Anderson song could be tightened for even greater precision.
Occasional use of 'we all know' or 'of course' can be a rhetorical shortcut that assumes too much of the hearer.
The term 'Big Idea' is repeated frequently; a few more synonyms could prevent slight stylistic fatigue.
criterion_a2_carefulness_and_precision.jargon_analysis: Excellent; theological terms are either avoided or translated into common experience (e.g., 'no reputation' for kenosis).

criterion_a3_musicality_and_rhythm.analysis: The sermon possesses a clear, conversational rhythm that is well-suited for oral delivery. Rutledge uses short, punchy sentences to create emphasis, particularly when describing the life of Jesus ('He was not rich, not a celebrity...'). There is a discernible cadence in the repetition of 'He rewrote the book of love,' which acts as a rhythmic anchor for the listener. However, the structure occasionally leans toward 'paper language' in the middle sections where historical explanation takes precedence over rhetorical flow. While the parallelism is effective, it lacks the high poetic musicality found in some of her more formal works. It is a functional, 'sober-Reformed' rhythm that prioritizes clarity over lyrical beauty, making it accessible but less 'musical' in a classical sense.
quotes: He was not rich, not a celebrity, not elected to anything, not commander of anything.
He rewrote it in his life and in his death...
Yes, there will be church fights. Yes, we will have disagreements. Yes, there will continue to be sin...
strengths: Effective use of anaphora ('Yes, there will...') to build momentum toward the end.
Short, declarative sentences that facilitate easy listening.
Good variation in sentence length between narrative and proclamation.
improvement_points: Some explanatory paragraphs are dense and could benefit from more rhythmic 'breathing room'.
The transition from the Columbine reference back to the text feels slightly abrupt in its cadence.
Could employ more alliteration or assonance to make key theological phrases more 'sticky' for the ear.
criterion_a3_musicality_and_rhythm.paper_language_diagnosis: Primarily oral language, though some explanatory sections retain a slightly academic weight.

domain_a_poetics_of_language.summary_language: The language is characterized by a 'sober beauty' that prioritizes clarity and theological depth over baroque ornamentation. Rutledge excels at 'stewardship of language,' translating profound Christological concepts into accessible, contemporary imagery without losing the 'staggering' nature of the Gospel. The imagery of the 'side of the road' cross and the 'Bill Gates' contrast are aesthetically effective because they 'refame' the familiar. While the musicality is more functional than poetic, the precision of word choice ensures that the 'Big Idea' remains central and un-obscured by religious jargon.

criterion_b1_narrative_arc.analysis: The sermon follows a clear 'homiletical plot' that begins with a 'fantasy' (Laurie Anderson's song) and moves toward the 'staggering reality' of the Gospel. Rutledge effectively 'upsets the equilibrium' by questioning the possibility of church unity, using the humorous but real example of the blue vs. red carpet. This creates a tension: is Paul's vision just a 'fantasyland'? The arc moves from human impossibility (selfishness, fighting, Columbine) to the divine 'Big Idea.' The turning point is the 'emptying' of Christ, which Rutledge frames as the ultimate 'rewriting.' The conclusion offers a resolution that doesn't ignore the ongoing reality of sin but places it within the larger frame of God's 'miracle of rewriting.' The movement from 'ugly people' to 'beautiful riches' provides a satisfying narrative closure.
quotes: Isn’t that just Paul imagining he’s king for a day? I don’t think it would work, do you?
Jesus rewrote the book of love. He wrote it in his own life.
The ugly people put Jesus on the Cross, but he never stopped loving us and he is going make us beautiful.
strengths: Strong opening that uses a pop-culture hook to introduce the central problem.
Clear movement from the 'trouble' (human selfishness) to the 'grace' (Christ's obedience).
Effective use of the 'rewriting' metaphor as a structural thread.
improvement_points: The middle section on the history of crucifixion, while informative, slightly slows the narrative momentum.
The connection to the Columbine shooting is powerful but could be more deeply integrated into the 'rewriting' arc.
The transition to the 'Communion' reference feels a bit tacked on at the end of a paragraph.
criterion_b1_narrative_arc.plot_diagnosis: A dynamic journey from the 'fantasy' of human love to the 'reality' of divine love.

criterion_b2_integration_text_and_contex.analysis: This is the sermon's strongest aesthetic feature. Rutledge masterfully 'reframes' the ancient Philippian hymn through the lens of modern performance art and contemporary tragedies. She respects the 'strangeness' of the biblical text (the 'morphe' of a slave) while making it speak directly to a post-Columbine congregation. The synthesis of Laurie Anderson's lyrics with Paul's theology is not a 'pasted-on' illustration but a genuine dialogue. She uses the context (church fights over carpets, school shootings, celebrity culture) to show why the 'Big Idea' of the cross is necessary. The 'reframing' is successful because it takes a familiar text and makes the hearer 'see' the radicality of the incarnation anew—not as a Christmas card, but as a 'godless death' for 'ugly people.'
quotes: God did not become the Bill Gates or the Donald Trump of his time.
Jesus rewrote the book of love... because you and I and Laurie Anderson and everybody else messed it up.
So the ugly people are going to get the money after all.
strengths: Brilliant integration of a secular song to illuminate a theological truth.
Honors the historical 'strangeness' of the cross while applying it to 1999.
Moves beyond simple 'application' to a true 'reframing' of reality.
improvement_points: Could have explored the 'performance artist' aspect of Laurie Anderson more to contrast with Christ's 'performance' on the cross.
The mention of Peter and Paul's fight could be more vividly connected to modern church conflicts.
The 'Bill Gates/Donald Trump' reference, while effective, is the only contemporary power-image; a second contrast could add depth.
criterion_b2_integration_text_and_contex.reframing_present: Strong presence of reframing; reality is viewed through the lens of the 'Big Idea' of the Cross.

criterion_b3_openness_vs_closedness.analysis: The sermon is largely an 'open work of art' in its acknowledgement of human complexity and the persistence of sin. Rutledge does not offer a 'happy ending' that ignores church fights or school shootings. She leaves the 'miracle of love' as a possibility that 'might' happen today, which invites the hearer to participate. However, the frequent use of the 'Big Idea' and the definitive 'He is the only rewriter we will ever need' leans toward a more 'closed' dogmatic structure. While she respects the mystery of the incarnation, her explanation of the atonement is quite systematic. The ending is an invitation, but it is a very directed one. It balances between the 'already' of the cross and the 'not yet' of the church's reality, allowing some room for the hearer's own struggle.
quotes: Yes, there will be church fights... there will continue to be sin until Jesus comes back.
This very day he might be calling you to perform a miracle of love...
What is bothering you right now? What is hindering love and unity...?
strengths: Acknowledges the 'ambivalence of existence' (ongoing sin and conflict).
Ends with an invitation to personal 'rewriting' rather than a moralistic command.
The 'ugly people' metaphor allows for various levels of personal appropriation.
improvement_points: The theological explanation of the atonement ('He stepped into our place...') is quite monovalent/closed.
Could leave more 'unanswered questions' regarding the 'how' of the miracle of love.
The conclusion 'It will make you laugh' is a bit prescriptive regarding the hearer's emotional response.
criterion_b3_openness_vs_closedness.open_work_diagnosis: Mostly open, though dogmatically firm in its Christological center.

domain_b_dramaturgy_of_structure.summary_structure: The macro-aesthetic structure is a well-crafted 'homiletical plot' that moves from the 'fantasy' of human effort to the 'staggering' reality of grace. The integration of text and context is superior, using 'reframing' to make the Philippian hymn feel urgent and contemporary. While the sermon is dogmatically grounded, it maintains enough openness to acknowledge the messiness of church life and the tragedy of the world. The narrative arc is sustained by the 'rewriting' metaphor, leading the hearer from a sense of 'ugliness' to the 'riches' of Christ's poverty.

kitsch_diagnosis.analysis: This sermon is a masterclass in avoiding religious kitsch. Rutledge explicitly rejects the 'attractive fantasy' and 'predictable' routine of church life. She refuses to offer 'immediate comfort' for the Columbine shootings or church conflicts, instead insisting on the 'horrible,' 'degrading,' and 'godless' nature of the cross. By calling the congregation 'ugly people,' she subverts the kitschy 'you are special' narrative often found in contemporary preaching. The emotion is authentic because it is rooted in the 'messy' reality of birth and the 'stench' of death, not in pre-chewed sentiment. She sustains the tension between the 'pure light' of God and the 'dehumanizing' cross without a cheap resolution.
examples_of_kitsch: The 'attractive fantasy' of Laurie Anderson's song (which the preacher identifies and rejects).
The potential kitsch of a 'happy' church where everyone agrees (which the preacher debunked with the carpet story).
authentic_moments: The acknowledgement that 'even the good things I do, I do for selfish reasons'.
The stark description of the cross as a 'death for slaves' by the side of the road.
kitsch_diagnosis.recommendation: Continue to lean into the 'strangeness' and 'offense' of the Gospel to maintain this high level of aesthetic authenticity.

space_for_grace_analysis.analysis: Rutledge creates significant 'Space for Grace' by emphasizing the 'unavailable' and 'staggering' nature of God's action. Grace is not a human 'Big Idea' but a divine 'miracle of rewriting' that comes from outside the human frame. She sustains the tension between our 'selfish, messed-up wills' and God's 'perfect love' without collapsing it into moralism. The sermon is not about 'trying harder' to be unselfish, but about being 'brought into the safety of his realm.' By framing the congregation as the 'ugly people' who receive the 'money,' she makes grace the primary actor. The 'space' is opened precisely where human possibility ends.
space_for_grace_analysis.tension_sustained: Yes, the tension between the 'already' of Christ's work and the 'not yet' of church conflict is maintained.
space_for_grace_analysis.mystery_respected: The mystery of the Incarnation is highlighted as something 'no human being could come up with.'
space_for_grace_analysis.moralization_vs_grace: Grace prevails; even the final call to action is framed as a 'miracle' God performs in the listener.
space_for_grace_analysis.recommendation: To open even more space, the preacher could occasionally dwell longer in the 'silence' of the cross before moving to the explanation of the 'rewriting'.

overall_aesthetics.summary: This sermon represents a high-quality example of 'Sober-Reformed' aesthetics infused with the 'New Homiletic's' emphasis on imagery and narrative. Fleming Rutledge avoids the pitfalls of both dry intellectualism and sentimental kitsch. The aesthetic power lies in the 'reframing' of the Philippian hymn through the surprising lens of Laurie Anderson’s performance art, creating a 'staggering' contrast between human fantasy and divine reality. The language is precise, 'stewardship of the word' is evident, and the imagery is concrete and visceral. While the structure is somewhat traditional in its theological explanation, the 'homiletical plot' successfully carries the listener from the 'trouble' of human selfishness to the 'grace' of Christ’s kenosis. It is an aesthetically 'honest' sermon that does not look away from the 'ugly' parts of life (Columbine, church fights) but frames them within the 'Big Idea' of a God who becomes a slave.
strengths_top_3: Masterful 'reframing' of the biblical text using contemporary culture (Laurie Anderson, Bill Gates).
Absolute avoidance of religious kitsch through 'honest' and 'visceral' language about the cross and sin.
Clear, multi-generational accessibility that maintains theological depth and precision.
improvement_points_top_3: Increase the 'musicality' and poetic rhythm of the prose in the more explanatory middle sections.
Deepen the 'openness' by allowing more room for the 'how' of the miracle in the conclusion.
Further integrate the 'Columbine' reference into the central 'rewriting' metaphor to maximize its dramaturgical impact.
overall_aesthetics.comparison_with_specialists: Fits Johan Cilliers (Reframing/Space for Grace) and Paul Scott Wilson (Imagery/Four Pages).
overall_aesthetics.audience_analysis: Appeals to intellectually curious hearers, those weary of religious kitsch, and a multi-generational congregation (including youth).
recommendations_for_next_sermon: Experiment with more 'poetic' sentence structures to enhance the 'musicality' of the proclamation.
Try an even more 'open' ending that leaves the congregation with a lingering image rather than a directed question.
Explore the 'sensory' world of the biblical text even more deeply (e.g., the sounds and smells of the 'slave' world).
overall_aesthetics.conclusion: A strong, aesthetically coherent sermon that honors the 'aesthetic turn' by making the 'how' of the message (the rewriting metaphor) inseparable from the 'what' (the kenosis of Christ). It is a model of how to preach 'Big Ideas' without becoming abstract, and how to be 'contemporary' without becoming kitschy. The sermon successfully opens a 'space for grace' in a world marked by 'ugliness' and conflict.
